bioghist.p: George Seldes (1890-1995) was an influential American investigative journalist and critic of the media and corporate power. He began his career in journalism when he was 16, working as a reporter for the Pittsburgh Leader. After a year at Harvard, he went to Europe to cover World War I. He remained in Europe after the war, working as a correspondent for the Chicago Tribune. He met and wrote about Freud, Alfred Adler, Isadora Duncan, Mussolini and Lenin. He left the Tribune in 1928 and worked as a freelancer, covering, among other things, the Spanish Civil War. He is the founder of In Fact, a weekly progressive newsletter, which he edited from 1940 to 1950. One of the early issues of the newsletter addressed the hazards of smoking and the suppression of this information by the mainstream press. He was the author of more than a dozen books, including You Can't Print That, Lords of the Press, The Great Quotations, The Great Thoughts, and his memoir, Witness to a Century. Seldes was married to Helen Larkin Wiesman (1905-1979). He was the brother of Gilbert Seldes, the critic and author.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the papers of George Seldes. The bulk of the materials are professional papers relating to his publication of his books and of In Fact. These papers include subject files of newspaper and magazine clippings; research notes; news bulletins; typed extracts of writings by others; typed and annotated drafts of articles by Seldes; manuscripts of Fads and Fascism, Sawdust Caesar, Tell the Truth and Run, You Can't Print That, Great Thoughts, Great Quotations, and other books; promotional materials for his publications; printed issues of In Fact and clippings of clippings of articles by Seldes in various newspapers and magazines; and correspondence with publishers, fellow journalists, readers, and other interested parties. Notable correspondents include Emma Goldman, J. Edgar Hoover, Ashley Montague; Norman Vincent Peale, William Shirer, Upton Sinclair, and Walter Winchell. There is some personal correspondence to George and Helen Seldes, as well, including letters from his niece Marian Seldes and her daughter Katharine Andres, and from Sylviane and Alvah Bessie. The collection includes a small number of photographs and newspaper and magazine profiles of Seldes.
